Message.Msg: Sybs: Let me clarify with the optimistic message. The reason I left McKinsey was to help usher in the next generation of productive investment -- nanotechnology. Yes, a buzzword. But, the essence of it is learning to manufacture with the finesse of biological systems from the bottom up. If you think about the chemical value of you, it approximates a few bucks... maybe. But, like the Visa commercial, you are priceless (entertaining at the least)... We will drive down the minimum efficient scale of production and increase the diversity and robustness of the economy and social stability in the process as we master nanotechnology based manufacturing (nanoengineering if you will). The modern top down manufacturing paradigm has been deflationary standards based diversity killing innovation that ultimately reduces the robustness of all of our systems developing fault intolerant high fixed cost winner take all systems. We have an opportunity to reinvent the way that we invent. And we will. I will give but one example of how innovation can change the future. Everyone bashed solar energy investment. They couldn't be more wrong. All extraction based industries will, over the longer haul, see increases cost per unit of energy (a simply corollary of the declining energy return on energy invested). In contrast, solar energy cost per peak watt has been decreasing exponentially over time (the first solar cells were designed for space and not cheap....). Unlike extraction based industries, human ingenuity and innovation continues to develop new material systems and new structures to optimize absorption efficiency and production economics (think of it as Moore's law for energy). WHEN, not if, the cost curves cross (because they most certainly will in time), the world changes in profoundly positive ways (solar is unique in that is it point of use energy generation without mass transport issues -- which will greatly enhance the robustness of our energy/economic systems). Your bearishness on the US is misplaced. One needs to distinguish between total wealth / income / QOL and median or average wealth / income / QOL. Europe is hosed. Demographics suck. Natural resources suck. Solar insolation sucks. Arable land per capita sucks. Japan is even worse... We think China is kicking tail, but run all the numbers on a per capita basis and you get a different view. The reality is that North America (including our largest trading partner to the North...) is very well situated for the future. We have large resource bases per capita on every metric. We still have significant industry and innvoation. We just simply need to stop pretending that trading creates value, wealth or improve quality of life and start investing in ourselves and in productive assets again. Sure, the next 3-5 years is going to be very painful across the globe. Maybe the next 10 years. But, I am convinced that this country will be the most attractive place to for the next generation to live...
